intro: Salix farrae, commonly known as the Farrae willow, is a species native to the mountainous regions of central and southern China. It is a deciduous shrub or small tree that typically grows to a height of 1–3 meters. The plant is characterized by its slender, often multi-branched stems and narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are usually hairy on the underside. Its flowers are catkins, which are typical of the Salicaceae family, and it produces small, oval fruits. Salix farrae is often found in moist, well-drained soils in forested or mountainous habitats.
